title: What individuals and events in history are a source of pride for Philippines? - Quora

response.answer_text: Unlike some other countries who have closed their borders from refugees, my country seems to be opening its borders to those fleeing persecution. One of the things I’m genuinely proud of is my country’s long history of accepting refugees, beginning with anti-Communist Russians (1917), to the Chinese escaping Japanese massacres back in World War II, to the Vietnamese during the Vietnam War, and recently, the Rohingya escaping genocide in Myanmar.  Jewish refugees in the Philippines (1940).  Rohingya Muslims I love what journalist and writer Patricia Evangelista says about the Philippines concerning refugees: “We know what we are. We are the port of last resort, and have little to offer beyond a separate peace. Yet I write this with pride, in the hope that there will always be a cluster of islands southwest of the Pacific, where no ship in need is called unwanted.” SOURCES: Philippines offers refuge to desperate migrants trapped on boats Philippines to accept refugees stuck at sea after being rejected across south-east Asia PINOY PRIDE | 9 times the Philippines welcomed refugees from 1923-2000 Duterte offers refugees a home in the Philippines The Rohingya and the port of last resort

Historically speaking: The Philippine Revolution, especially the Philippine Independence DayThe Philippine-American War, especially the Battle of Tirad PassThe Second World War, where the Filipinos refused to bow to yet another oppressor.The EDSA Revolution, where the Filipinos refused to bow to yet another oppressor, this time one of their own kind, not a foreigner.Speaking of individuals: Filipinos who are involved in the historical events stated above: Jose Rizal, Andres Bonifacio, Emilio Jacinto, Emilio Aguinaldo, Gregorio del Pilar, Benigno Aquino.. etc.Filipinos who are famous worldwide and proudly showed to the world what Filipinos are, such as Manny Pacquiao, Lea Salonga, Pia Wurstback… etc.
